title: The Highway of Tears (And Maybe Hope) | STUFF YOU SHOULD KNOW

production of iHeart
[Music]
Radio hey and welcome to the podcast i'm
Josh and there's Chuck and Jerry's here
too and this is Stuff You Should
Know the Man this is a bummer edition
yeah the the Zero Laughs edition uh
because we're talking about the Highway
of Tears mhm and uh there's no other way
around it this is just a devastating
topic
yeah and we should tell people I mean
The Highway of Tears is fairly famous
it's um kind of been in the in the news
and in pop culture I guess for a while
um I guess at least since the '9s but
really in the early 2000s I think is
when it picked up regardless it is a
stretch of desolate highway that runs
from uh in British Columbia up in Canada
from the um the port city of Prince
Roupert uh all the way into the interior
uh to Prince George and it's I think 720
km almost 450 miles and it's known as
Highway 16 officially but the stretches
of this highway are so desolate so
remote and so sparssely populated that
it is become a haven for murderers who
pick people up mostly women mostly
indigenous women on this road and either
um make them disappear forever or murder
them and it's it's endemic in this area
so much so that it's caught national
attention it just how poorly this group
of women are being treated and uh and
their families as well yeah it's uh you
know as you'll see it's um and you know
there are many reasons for this but it's
a a heavily hitchhiked road and uh that
can be very dangerous um and so a lot of
times these are are hitchhikers people
just trying to get from one place to
another uh and like you said they are uh
you know either sexually assaulted or
murdered or both uh and this these are
the people that you know like they found
bodies there are you know dozens and
dozens more than these dozens uh who
have survived attacks and rapes along
that stretch of highway so um you know
it's no secret why it's called the
Highway of Tears uh big thanks to Livia
for enduring uh this topic and helping
us out with it and big thanks to Al
Jazer where she got a lot of um
information from a six-part series they

kind of coverage you would get when say

kind of coverage about how this group of
people have just been totally
um basically left on their own to deal
with something like this that they have
they don't have the resources to deal
with this and it's just such a terrible
story the story is so much larger than
this collection of murders um but at the
core that's what it comes down to just
women who were treated like disposable
beings yeah and the whole thing starts
um at the very at the very earliest as
far as anyone knows the first murder
that's become part of what you would
call the cannon of the Highway of Tears
murders and and abductions um started in
1969 uh a woman named Levvenia Gloria
Moody uh was murdered on Highway 16 and
it went um kind of went along like that
for a while there was but but no one had
kind of put together this whole group of
people and called it the highway of
tears and they wouldn't for years to
come but at the time there was enough
going on that they had coined this term
the highway murders and by 1981 enough
um women and girls had been murdered or
gone missing along Highway 16 that a
group of Royal Canadian-mounted police
detectives from all over British
Columbia and I think Alberta got
together and decided to kind of compare
notes and see if if if they could solve
some of these unsolved cases yes
absolutely um while this was going on uh
you know when when the cops were sort of
slowly uh coming around to the idea that
there was a specific problem along the
stretch um the families were getting
involved the families of the missing the
families of uh those who were found dead
and you know they organized their own

this was in June of

went to go meet up with a friend uh to
go to some uh you know end of the year
school graduation parties uh she never
got there and her mom Matilda was like
the cops don't really seem to care much
that this happened and so the locals got
together and they started organizing
they started doing you know going on

other members of her family in the

which became an annual thing yeah there

it's got to be really tough to take and
